"Anyway, just use common sense and treat your fellow stalkers with some respect and you should get along just fine out here."

"Wake up! Anthony, wake up!" The heavenly bliss of sleep was unceremoniously broken by the distant call roaring in my ear. With a trained but nonetheless reluctant motion I swung my body up from the sleeping bag. "What is it, Erwin?" I grumbled, assuming the most menacing expression they my tired self could do. But even as those words left my mouth, I could immediately sense that something was very off. The air was still, devoid of the distant hummings that always came from the Brain Scorcher.

Following the increase in emissions and the subsequent changing of the Zone's anomalous activity, the road to the Great Swamps opened up and certain individuals began moving in on what they hoped was an area of unharvested bounty and safe haven from authority. These people, dubbed the Renegades, soon got themselves into a turf war with the resident Clear Sky after committing several gruesome acts against fellow stalkers.

The two Renegades on the sandbank, Bolt and Gurkha, had spotted a flesh sleeping in the reeds, and seeing a potential meal, began closing in. Bolt was so fixated on getting close enough to finish the pig with his knife that he did not notice Gurkha leaving behind. In the pitch-black darkness, a figure emerged from the water behind Gurkha, and a gloved hand stopped him from screaming. Bolt had gotten to the flesh and indulged in his sadistic slashing of the creature. Only when a knife slid into his back did he realize: it was too late.

Giorgi felt pain everywhere in his body. His feet ached, sharp cuts all over his legs and arms. He could see a faint spark ahead, and in the dim light Giorgi recognized a blade in his hand. It was a rusty old knife. Giorgi took a wobbly step towards the light, then another. What happened to him? He could not remember the last weeks, hell, barely anything from the last months. He remembered sneaking into the Zone, then joining Pitman's gang. Giorgi's head ached as he tried to push memories into the forefront, but all he found was blackness.

“Yob tvoyu matj! Friendly fire, you fucking idiots!” I shouted, wrenching his gun around to point at the approaching attackers. “We’re on the same side, blyadj! Bullets go that way!” To his credit, the Freedomer took my advice and let loose with more rounds. As I watched him firing, an enemy shot sparked off my shoulder armour. I whirled and zeroed in on the enemy, before putting a round in their gas mask eyepiece.

"Don't shoot, it's just a boar. Let's slip past quietly, we don't want to create any unwanted attention to ourselves. Who knows how many fucking Freedom, Duty, or worse: Mercs are out there. Just grab the rest of the loot and let's go. Now!"

The fire cracked silently as four Stalkers sat around it. The night was silent, only a small wind and the rustling of grass and leaves to fill the ears. One of the men spoke up suddenly: "Have you children heard the tale of the Monolith?" Hearing no replies, the man continued, "You see, in the center of the Zone, stands the Nuclear Power Plant. Many have tried to reach it, and all of them have failed. Their ambitions were mountains of artefacts and gold, and anything else their greedy minds could think of."

The rumors, quietly spoken aboard the Skadovsk, had proven true. Some long-forgotten administration building had been discovered by an explorer, one who had bolted at the sight, later claiming that the building felt "cursed" and that the red light shining above its doors was the ghastly eye of some monster as yet unknown to the Zone. "Superstitious nonsense to one who understands the Zone's ways," the stalker thought.

It was when he turned to leave the office that he realized- at some point the sounds of the storm had gone silent, much more quickly than should have been possible. The worry worming into his mind crystallized- why would a building have laid open for so long with none of the Zone's wildlife settling inside? Fear gripped his heart as he bolted back the way he came, boots clomping against the faded rug, only to skid to a stop as he came to the entrance. Only white concrete met his gaze. The entrance had vanished.

Tiger watched the mutated animals for a few seconds. He had kept himself alive this long on a single principle – the less trouble you cause, the less trouble you get – but the alternative to culling the four-eared creatures was a twenty-minute detour through dense vegetation. He had no special love for boars, and they were hardly endangered anyway. "Are you a fast shot?" he asked, swinging the Mosin off his back.

The Barrier had been here for as long as stalkers controlled the area. The military, loners, mercs and Duty had all manned its barricades at one time or another, but now it belonged to Freedom. It was an ominous place, the gnarly trees further up the cracked and cratered road standing as silent portents of what lay beyond: the impassable realm of the Brain Scorcher, overlooking the eastern Red Forest and blocking the way to Pripyat and the Zone's center. Past here, none but zombies and Monolith troops could survive.

The roar of the rain became a dull thrum as he entered the building, his flashlight playing across dust-covered floors and furniture, the interior remarkably intact. Good- it meant that mutants hadn't made it a nest. Still, something itched at the back of his mind as he crept about, checking desks and cabinets, until he came upon what looked like an administrator's office. Paydirt! An object he'd never seen the likes of before hovered an arm's length above the stately oak desk, glowing softly, resembling two entwined rings of silver the width of his hand...

On the face of it, this was many a stalker's dream employment: a straightforward contract to escort some snotty but rich tourists around the countryside for a day or two, shoot a few animals and come back. Tiger knew better: Lugard's cannon looked impressive but it was a sportsman's weapon, carefully crafted and precisely adjusted. The Zone wasn't a place for such things – it was a place for loose tolerances, scuff-resistant finishes and generous magazine capacities. The notion of going to a place like the Red Forest seemed like trouble.

I came to the Zone trying to find a new artefact and strike it rich up north. I had no idea the Monolith would reactivate the Brain Scorcher and invade. I would give anything to leave this God forsaken place and return home — But now there was no way out. My only chance would be to fight my way to the Wish Granter. To make a last, desperate wish to end this nightmare, or die trying. What choice did I have?

I leaped up from cover and prepared to send another grenade at the Exo-Bandit, when I noticed he wasn’t moving; the Bandit was standing in one spot, his limbs quivering. My finger tightened on my trigger. Before I could go for the kill, the bandit jammed his AK’s barrel under the lip of his armored helmet, and blew his own head off. The rusted Exoskeleton jerked with the Bandit’s death spasms, and a thick red soup started oozing out from under the helmet; after a second, the Exo’s limbs went limp and the dead Bandit crumpled like a ragdoll.

All I remember was darkness and the cold creeping into me when I saw it... A bright light that filled me with warmth and spoke to me. "Come to me, you will gain what you deserve." Sometimes I see images of an older man with tears running down his face saying, "don't go we will be okay." Was that my father? Either way it does not matter. The Monolith must be defended from the heretics.

"This is General Tachenko, where are you? What are your coordinates? We will come and extract you, we just need a response God damnit!" General Tachenko banged his fist on the desk in anger. "We just lost an entire unit and now Freedom have complete control over Yanov!"
Collateral damage can be justified, if the gain outweighs the cost. How much do you think your faction members are worth?
I exist and I find it nauseating.
